habitat_description:
The canyon lizard occurs in western Texas from Edwards to Presidio Counties. In Mexico, this species is found in eastern Chihuahua, south central Coahuila, and extreme northern Durango (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Conant and Collins 1991; Dixon 2000; Olson 1979).

The habitat is described as bare rock, talus, scree, and cliff associations. This is a species known to burrow in or using soil, leaf litter, and fallen logs. But also, found on canyon walls and rocky slopes with sparse vegetation. Usually found occupying steep rock faces where cover is provided by crevices.

Generally found in areas with sparse vegetation where rocks, soil, fallen leaves provide the most cover opportunities.
